title: CBC Radio
text:
While thousands of Canadians have a pretty good handle on the country's overall inflation trends, they are less clear about how prices have fluctuated for specific categories of goods, according to results from CBC Radio's Cost of Living inflation guessing game.

In early September, as part of the CBC Radio program's debut episode, the Cost of Living launched an interactive online quiz to test Canadians' knowledge of inflation trends in specific categories from 1998 to 2018.

Over the course of three weeks, more than 10,000 people took part in the game, which was created in conjunction with the Cost of Living team by designer Olivier Ballou.

Few players guessed that prices actually could go down. - Inflation Game designer Olivier Ballou

"In some cases, the average guesses were quite close to the actual values," said Ballou, who characterized the results as a great example of the "wisdom of crowds."

CBC Radio's new business and economics show, Cost of Living, airs on CBC Radio One every Saturday at 11:30 a.m. (12 p.m. NT) or online anytime at CBC Listen.

The designer also noted that few players realized inflation rates could mean that actual costs in some categories had decreased over the years.

"For clothes and cars, few players guessed that prices actually could go down," said Ballou.

Hardest to guess? Cars, clothes, classrooms

The changes in vehicles, clothing and tuition prices emerged as the trickiest trends to pinpoint.

"Players were way off when it came to tuition, but at least the estimates were in the correct, upward direction," said Ballou.

Not sure what inflation even is?

Click here for the Cost of Living primer on the subject.

The game is not an official poll. Conclusions drawn from respondents have not been weighted by geography, age, or any other factor to reflect the population or demographic composition of Canada.

So what were the results?

To visualize the results, a sample of 200 responses were randomly selected to avoid overwhelming the graphs with thousands of lines.

This graph shows a selection of Canadians' guesses on how much the cost of vehicles went up from 1998 to 2018, according to Statistics Canada. (Olivier Ballou)

This graph shows a selection of Canadians' guesses on how much the cost of tuition went up from 1998 to 2018, according to Statistics Canada. (Olivier Ballou)

This graph shows a selection of Canadians' guesses on how much the cost of clothing went up from 1998 to 2018, according to Statistics Canada. (Olivier Ballou)
description: Canadians who tried guessing inflation rates have a pretty good handle on Canada's overall pricing trends but are less clear about how prices have fluctuated for specific categories of goods, according to results from CBC Radio’s Cost of Living inflation guessing game.
